explanation.text: The claim asserts that Al₅₀Zn₅₀ forms a single solid phase at all temperatures below 700K. This is a universal claim requiring single-phase behavior throughout the entire temperature range.

CALPHAD thermodynamic calculations using the COST 507 database at 50 at.% Al, 50 at.% Zn, and 1 atm pressure show that at 300K, the equilibrium phase assemblage consists of FCC_A1 (50.3%) and HCP_ZN (49.7%), clearly indicating a two-phase region.
At 500K, the same CALPHAD calculations show FCC_A1 (53.8%) and HCP_ZN (46.2%), confirming the two-phase region persists at intermediate temperatures.
Only at 650K does the alloy become single-phase FCC_A1 (100%), indicating that single-phase behavior only emerges near the upper end of the claimed temperature range.

The presence of two solid phases with substantial fractions (~50% each) at 300K and 500K provides decisive counterexamples to the universal claim, which requires single-phase behavior at ALL temperatures below 700K. The two-phase region spans approximately 90% of the stated temperature range (from ~1K to ~600-650K).

This finding is consistent with the known Al-Zn phase diagram, which shows limited mutual solubility at low temperatures, forming FCC (Al-rich) and HCP (Zn-rich) two-phase regions at intermediate compositions.

claim_statement.citation: Al₅₀Zn₅₀ forms a single solid phase <700K

calphad_summary.citation: At Al50Zn50 and 1 atm, the alloy is not single-phase over 0–700 K. Two-phase solid equilibrium (FCC_A1 + HCP_ZN) exists at low and intermediate temperatures; HCP_ZN dissolves on heating. By ~650 K, the alloy becomes single-phase FCC_A1 and remains so up to 700 K.

baseline_knowledge.citation: Al-Zn system is well-known to have limited mutual solubility at low T, forming FCC (Al-rich) + HCP (Zn-rich) two-phase regions at intermediate compositions
